newsitem.title: UK: Planned far-right broadcast in Britain condemned.
newsitem.headline: Planned far-right broadcast in Britain condemned.

text.p: Anti-racist groups on Friday condemned a planned political broadcast on BBC television by an ultra right-wing party that advocates repatriation of non-whites and the re-introduction of capital punishment in Britain.

The British National Party (BNP) broadcast ahead of the May 1 general election has been approved by BBC lawyers and is awaiting the green light from producers on taste and decency standards, a spokesman for the national broadcaster said.

"There are millions of African and Asian tax-payers in this country whose tax contributions are now going to be used to fund a racially divisive propagandist political election broadcast from the BNP," said Lee Jasper, chairman of National Black Alliance, an umbrella group of anti-racist pressure groups.
"It cannot be right that the money is going to be used to resource what can only be described as a race hate campaign against black British citizens," he said.

The BNP has been blamed by anti-racist groups for a number of racially motivated attacks, particularly in rundown east London. Asked whether the BNP was a racist organisation, party chairman John Tyndall said it depended on the use of the word.
"If you mean we hate other races, no. If you mean that we put our own race first and want to preserve it, yes," he told Reuters.
Tyndall championed the rights of "our own people" which he said were British-born whites. Europeans were acceptable because they were basically from the same culture, he said.

Tyndall said the party advocated a withdrawal from the European Union, a tough stance on crime including the restoration of capital punishment and protectionist trade measures against imports to stimulate the economy.
"Its (BNP policies) are very unpopular among people ...who are against free speech," Tyndall said. "The ordinary British public might disagree with us but would not dispute our right to be heard."
The BNP is fielding 56 candidates on May 1 but has yet to win a seat in parliament.

"Any party fielding 50 candidates or more does qualify for a party election broadcast," BBC spokesman Kevan McClair said. "The requirements above that is that the broadcast must be legal and must meet acceptable standards of broadcasting."
Jasper said any political organisation that advocated the denial of democratic freedoms should automatically forfeit its right to enjoy the benefits of a democratic process.

"I am a black British citizen, third generation, am I to be deported?" Jasper asked. "That they should be able to propagate such an idea at the taxpayers' expense in a modern multi-cultural democracy in 1997 is a gross insult to black and Jewish communities throughout this country."
Tyndall was responsible for his party's biggest success in a by-election in the east London seat of Dagenham in May 1994. He won 1,511 votes or 7.03 percent of the total vote.
If the four-minute BNP programme gets the go-ahead it would be broadcast on the BBC's two television channels on April 25, the BBC said.
It would also be heard twice on BBC radio. Britain's commercial television network also shows political broadcasts.

In October 1993 several protesters were injured when Britain's biggest anti-racist march in 15 years turned violent. About 20,000 protesters were prevented by police from reaching a bookshop in southeast London which served as BNP headquarters.
The British Broadcasting Corporation is funded by a licence fee paid by television owners. Its board of governors is appointed by the government.
